It bridges the gap between back-end and front-end development, enabling you to implement complex front-end behaviors directly within your Django templates.</p>\n<p>In theory, you should be able to include many interactive elements such as navigation menus, hovered class changes, instant updates etc. with simple, easy to understand Django template tags.</p>\n<p><em> <strong>Simplicity</strong>: Add interactive elements using familiar Django template tags.</em></p>\n<p><em> <strong>Productivity</strong>: Achieve more with less code using pre-built modules.</em></p>\n<p><em> <strong>Flexibility</strong>: Works seamlessly with HTMX and Tailwind CSS, or standalone.</em></p>\n<p><em> <strong>Maintainability</strong>: Keep front-end logic close to your HTML structure for improved readability.</em></p>\n<p><em> <strong>Gentle Learning Curve</strong>: Easy to adopt for developers familiar with Django templates.</em></p>\n<h2>How It Works</h2>\n<p>Django-Spellbook introduces a set of powerful "spells" (modules) that you can invoke in your templates. Here\'s a simple example using the ActionInvoker module:</p>\n<pre><code class="language-code"> {% load action_invoker_tags %} \n{% invoke_action \n\t"click" "add-class" "this" "my-button" \n\tconfig=\'class:active\' \n %}</code></pre>\n<p>This spell adds the \'active\' class to an element with the ID \'my-button\' when it\'s clicked, all without writing a single line of JavaScript.</p>\n<h2>Why Choose Django-Spellbook?</h2>\n<p>Django-Spellbook solves several common pain points in web development:</p>\n<p>- Reduces the need for complex JavaScript setups</p>\n<p>- Bridges the gap between back-end and front-end development</p>\n<p>- Enables rapid prototyping of interactive features</p>\n<p>- Promotes consistency in front-end interactions across your project</p>\n<h2>Getting Started</h2>\n<p>Ready to add some magic to your Django project? Let\'s begin with a simple installation:</p>\n<pre><code class="language-code">pip install django-spellbook</code></pre>\n<p>Then, add \'django_spellbook\' to your INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py:</p>\n<pre><code class="language-code">INSTALLED_APPS = [\n # ...\n \'django_spellbook\',\n # ...\n]</code></pre>\n<p>Now you\'re ready to start casting spells in your templates!</p>\n<h2>Next Steps</h2>\n<p>Explore our documentation to learn more about:</p>\n<p>- <a href="./modules.md">Available Modules</a></p>\n<p>- <a href="./best-practices.md">Best Practices</a></p>\n<p>- <a href="./advanced-usage.md">Advanced Usage</a></p>\n<p>Welcome to the world of Django-Spellbook, where crafting interactive web applications is as simple as casting a spell!</p> {% endverbatim %} ', 'children': {}}}}, '--Modules': {'children': {'ActionInvoker': {'children': {'API Reference': {'children': {'JavaScript Class.md': {'title': 'JavaScript Class', 'url_path': '/--Modules/ActionInvoker/API Reference/JavaScript Class', 'last_modified': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 11, 7, 44, 6, 81517), 'content': ' {% verbatim %} <h1>JavaScript Class</h1>\n<h3>JavaScript Class</h3>\n<p>The `ActionInvoker` class is responsible for handling the front-end logic of the module.</p>\n<pre><code class="language-javascript">new ActionInvoker(config)</code></pre>\n<p>The `config` object should include:</p>\n<p>- `event`: The event to listen for</p>\n<p>- `action`: The action to perform</p>\n<p>- `targetId`: The ID of the target element</p>\n<p>- `strategy`: The strategy for selecting elements (optional, default: "this")</p>\n<p>- `bindedId`: The ID of the element to bind the event to (optional)</p>\n<p>- `fireOnce`: Whether the action should only fire once (optional, default: false)</p> {% endverbatim %} ', 'children': {}}, 'Template Tag.md': {'title': 'Template Tag', 'url_path': '/--Modules/ActionInvoker/API Reference/Template Tag', 'last_modified': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 11, 7, 43, 15, 801790), 'content': ' {% verbatim %} <h1>Template Tag</h1>\n<h3>Python Template Tag</h3>\n<p>The `invoke_action` template tag is used to initialize ActionInvoker instances in Django templates.</p>\n<pre><code class="language-python">{% invoke_action \n event action strategy target_id \n config=\'\' %}</code></pre>\n<p><strong>Parameters:</strong></p>\n<p>- `event`: The event to listen for (e.g., "on-load")</p>\n<p>- `action`: The action to take (e.g., "click")</p>\n<p>- `strategy`: The strategy to use for selecting elements (e.g., "all")</p>\n<p>- `target_id`: The ID of the element for the action to target.</p>\n<p>- `config`: Optional. Additional configuration parameters as a string</p> {% endverbatim %} ', 'children': {}}}}, 'Advanced Usage.md': {'title': 'Advanced Usage', 'url_path': '/--Modules/ActionInvoker/Advanced Usage', 'last_modified': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 11, 7, 39, 16, 771092), 'content': ' {% verbatim %} <h1>Advanced Usage</h1> {% endverbatim %} ', 'children': {}}, 'Introduction.md': {'title': 'Introduction', 'url_path': '/--Modules/ActionInvoker/Introduction', 'last_modified': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 11, 10, 2, 2, 978594), 'content': " {% verbatim %} <h2>Purpose and Philosophy</h2>\n<p>The ActionInvoker module was born out of the need to simplify the creation of dynamic, interactive web applications within the Django framework. Our philosophy is rooted in the belief that backend developers should be able to create rich, interactive user experiences without having to switch contexts or languages.</p>\n<p>By leveraging the familiar Django template syntax, ActionInvoker empowers developers to add sophisticated interactivity to their applications without leaving the comfort of their Django environment. This approach not only speeds up development but also maintains a clear separation of concerns, keeping your interactive logic close to your HTML structure.</p>\n<h2>Key Benefits</h2>\n<p>1. <strong>Reduced JavaScript Dependency</strong>: Minimize the amount of custom JavaScript needed for common interactive elements.</p>\n<p>2. <strong>Improved Developer Experience</strong>: Utilize familiar Django template syntax for frontend interactions.</p>\n<p>3. <strong>Faster Prototyping</strong>: Quickly implement interactive features directly in your templates.</p>\n<p>4. <strong>Enhanced Maintainability</strong>: Keep your interactive logic close to your HTML, improving code readability and maintainability.</p>\n<p>5. <strong>Seamless Integration</strong>: Works harmoniously with other Django features and third-party libraries like HTMX and Tailwind CSS.</p>\n<h2>Real-World Applications</h2>\n<p>ActionInvoker shines in various scenarios, such as:</p>\n<p>- Creating dynamic navigation menus</p>\n<p>- Implementing form validation feedback</p>\n<p>- Managing modal dialogs and popups</p>\n<p>- Handling dynamic content loading</p>\n<p>- Implementing interactive data visualizations</p>\n<p>By providing a declarative way to define these interactions, ActionInvoker helps maintain a clean separation between your application's structure and its behavior.</p>\n<h3>Read Next</h3> {% endverbatim %} ", 'children': {}}, 'Settings.md': {'title': 'Settings', 'url_path': '/--Modules/ActionInvoker/Settings', 'last_modified': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 11, 7, 41, 27, 674379), 'content': ' {% verbatim %} <h1>Settings</h1>\n<p>- `ALLOWED_EVENTS`: A set of allowed event types (\'on-load\')</p>\n<p>- `ALLOWED_ACTIONS`: A set of allowed actions (\'click\', \'toggle\', \'add-class\', \'remove-class\')</p>\n<p>- `VALID_STRATEGIES`: A list of valid strategies for selecting elements (\'all\', \'first\', \'last\', \'none\', \'random\', \'byText\', \'this\')</p>\n<p><strong>Example</strong>:</p>\n<pre><code class="language-python"># Add a new event\nALLOWED_EVENTS.append(\'new-event\')</code></pre> {% endverbatim %} ', 'children': Usage Examples

Here are some examples of how to use the ActionInvoker module in your Django templates:

1. Add a class to an element on click:

{% load action_invoker_tags %}
{% invoke_action "click" "add-class" "this" "my-button" config='class:active' %}
<button id="my-button"
		class="sb-btn">
		Click me
</button>
.sb-btn active {
}

2. Click all buttons in a group on page load:

{% endverbatim %} July 11, 2024, 7:46 a.m.
